and to allow freshmen to become acquainted with all of the campus

rushing season, William 0. Corkran, president of the Interfraternity
Board, has announced a plan whereby first semester "open houses" will
he allowed.

The Rushing Agreement 1933-34

"Rushing is hereby defined as attempting by any means to persuade
a man in his first year of residence
in the University to join a particular specified fraternity, bidding,
Pledging, entertaining, dating, sponsoring an entertainment, or allowing a man not belonging to a college
fraternity in his first year of residence to enter a fraternity house
Or homes of fraternity men, other
than specified below." The fraternity
house above stated includes fraterriitY houses at other colleges. Men
in their first year of residence shall
be permitted to ride to their homes
from the University, and from their
homes to the University with fraternity men only after obtaining
Permission from the board. Congregationc of men of one fraternity
and men in their first year of residence in localities off the campus
shall be construed as rushing. More

Saturday Nile Dance

states will be one of the most successful seasons in the existence of
the Cotillion Board, Bob Powell
has announced a third dance to be
held on Saturday night, October 21,
at Levering. Music is to be supplied by Al Mason and his orchestra.
The Board is beginning the new
season of dances by sponsoring different bands with the purpose of
feeling out public opinion, he said.
The Townsmen entertained for the
opening, and last week Billie Birke
and his Royal Guards were engaged.
According to Powell, other orchestras may be selected. He further stated that suggestions were invited and that a sincere effort was
being made to please the public.
Acting under the plan announced
last week to donate the season's income to finance the football training
table, the Board is asking for the
student body's support of the forthcoming dances. In view of the fact
that the proceeds are benefiting the
University directly, a large attendance is desired.
Tickets will be on sale in front of
Levering Hall on Thursday and
Friday from 11 to 2. The price
will be 80 cents to students possessing S. A. C. cards. Admission at
the door will be $1, and S. A. C.
cards will not be accepted at that
time

Figures released by the office of
the registrar indicated that 289 entering students and 586 returning
students registered for the college
year 1933-34.
Compared to the
statistics for the corresponding time
in October, 1932, there is a decrease this year of 45 students. Of
the number registering, there were
150 in the College of Arts and Sciences; 112, in the School of Engineering; and 27, in the School of
Business Economics.

now a man and then to proceed to treat
him as a boy is like taking the apples
out of apple pie. It is contrary to the
principles of which administration and
faculty members have been constantly reminding us. But it's heartening to know
that we now have a Student Council
which is progressive enough to realize
that the old ruling is of no more use.
The road of the Council is a difficult
one, but having the confidence of the
students with it there is every probability that we shall be led out of the woods
in a short while. As our contribution to
this "confidence" we promise not to take
up our pens to din for action, as we so
often did last year—that is, we won't if
we keep getting action.

The Evening's Promising
THEY'RE going to revive it tonight—
the discussion of that burning problem
of civilization for centuries past—racial
and religious persecution. Rabbi Stephen
S. Wise, of New York, comes to the
Supper Club to denounce the Nazi terrorism in Germany, where he spent some
time this summer.
Interest, information, and stimulation
should feature the meeting if we may
depend upon the attitude which Rabbi
Wise indicates in a statement he made
recently. We quote from recollection:
"The human vocabulary cannot describe
the condition (in Germany); only the
language of Hell can approximate it!"
We are glad that at least he intends to
deal in concrete statements and not in
vague generalities.
We would like to urge that some of
the more competent among the diners this
evening give Rabbi Wise a stiff quizzing
on the subject. To have gotten the hold
which it seems to have upon the German people Hitlerism must have something to recommend it—at least to
Germans. Whether it be an innate longing of a national culture which it satisfies,
or merely the devilish terrorism of an
individual in complete power is a matter
of some interest.

Active work on the 1934 Hullabaloo will begin with a meeting
of the members and candidates for
the business staff of the yearbook
at 12:20, in the publication's office,
Levering Hall. Candidates for the
editorial and photographic staffs, as
well as present members of these
staffs, will meet for assignments on
Friday, October 20, at 12:20.
According to Ted Stern, editorin-chief of the annual, the edition
will present a complete departure
from all previous standards. The
size of the book will be greatly increased. Individual photographs of
every undergraduate, classified according to year of residence in the
University, will be included in the
book.
Picture Calendar

Another feature is to be a ninepage picture calendar of the year
in retrospect. Instead of the usual
photographs of the campus buildings, the yearbook will contain
thirty-six original etchings of the
various parts of the University.
The plates for these etchings have
been, for the most part, presented
by the artists themselves.

shall also be construed as rushing.
The Dormitory is defined as the
home of either a fraternity man or
of a freshman. The president of the
Interfraternity Board has the authority to permit any special trips
to be made by freshmen and fraternity men. In the event that such
permission is granted, the president
is to be held personally liable to
the board to see that there are no
infractions of these rules by the
fraternity or fraternities receiving
such permission.
The rushing season for the year
1933-34 shall begin at 8:00 a. m. on
Wednesday, February 7, before
which time no engagement or date
for any time during the rushing season shall be made by fraternity men
with men in their first year of residence. Rushing shall be permitted
only on or after the said Wednesday
except as stated below.
On Friday, October 20, November 3 and 17, December 8 and 15,
and January 12, freshmen may visit
the various fraternity houses beginning at 8:00 a. m. until 1:00 a. m.
Lunch may be served to the freshmen but they must not stay to dinner. The freshmen may return later
in the evening to dance by the radio

as may be chosen. The fraternities
may not have an orchestra.
Invitations to these open houses
must be placed in the hands of an
officer of the board by the fraternities on Monday of the week of
their open house. The officer will
place the invitations in the University P. 0. boxes of the first year
men on that Monday. After Monday of each week of open houses invitations are unrestricted for that
week.
The fraternities should be divided
into three groups, each group having two open houses. The groups
shall have open houses alternately
on the dates given above.
Beginning on Thursday, February 8, 1934, a period of allotted
open houses shall exist, on which
days the designated fraternities shall
be permitted to entertain men in
their first year of residence, provided
that said entertainment shall be restricted to said fraternity house, the
Barn, or Levering Hall* On such
allotted days the designated fraternities shall enjoy priority over all
other fraternities, but in the event
that two fraternities shall share the
SANDWICHES

If parties are held on these days, the
freshmen must bear their share of
any expenses. There shall be a
silent period from midnight, Saturday, February 17, until 3:00 p. m.
Sunday, February 18, during which
time there shall be no communication of any sort between fraternity
men (including alumni) and men
in their first year of residence.
After presentation of bids at 3:00
p. m. Sunday, February 18, there
shall be open and unrestricted rushing. No fraternity man is to be at
the home of the freshman before
2:45 p. m. Sunday, February 18.
The constitution of the Interfraternity Board provides for a fine of
from $1.00 to $100.00 for any infringement of the above rules. Any
violations of the agreement shall be
tried by the Interfraternity Board.
It is the duty of each and every
member of the Board to report any
violation of the rules set down
above.

The Rushing Agreement 1933-34

"Rushing is hereby defined as attempting by any means to persuade
a man in his first year of residence
in the University to join a particular specified fraternity, bidding,
Pledging, entertaining, dating, sponsoring an entertainment, or allowing a man not belonging to a college
fraternity in his first year of residence to enter a fraternity house
Or homes of fraternity men, other
than specified below." The fraternity
house above stated includes fraterriitY houses at other colleges. Men
in their first year of residence shall
be permitted to ride to their homes
from the University, and from their
homes to the University with fraternity men only after obtaining
Permission from the board. Congregationc of men of one fraternity
and men in their first year of residence in localities off the campus
shall be construed as rushing. More

Saturday Nile Dance

states will be one of the most successful seasons in the existence of
the Cotillion Board, Bob Powell
has announced a third dance to be
held on Saturday night, October 21,
at Levering. Music is to be supplied by Al Mason and his orchestra.
The Board is beginning the new
season of dances by sponsoring different bands with the purpose of
feeling out public opinion, he said.
The Townsmen entertained for the
opening, and last week Billie Birke
and his Royal Guards were engaged.
According to Powell, other orchestras may be selected. He further stated that suggestions were invited and that a sincere effort was
being made to please the public.
Acting under the plan announced
last week to donate the season's income to finance the football training
table, the Board is asking for the
student body's support of the forthcoming dances. In view of the fact
that the proceeds are benefiting the
University directly, a large attendance is desired.
Tickets will be on sale in front of
Levering Hall on Thursday and
Friday from 11 to 2. The price
will be 80 cents to students possessing S. A. C. cards. Admission at
the door will be $1, and S. A. C.
cards will not be accepted at that
time

The Evening's Promising
THEY'RE going to revive it tonight—
the discussion of that burning problem
of civilization for centuries past—racial
and religious persecution. Rabbi Stephen
S. Wise, of New York, comes to the
Supper Club to denounce the Nazi terrorism in Germany, where he spent some
time this summer.
Interest, information, and stimulation
should feature the meeting if we may
depend upon the attitude which Rabbi
Wise indicates in a statement he made
recently. We quote from recollection:
"The human vocabulary cannot describe
the condition (in Germany); only the
language of Hell can approximate it!"
We are glad that at least he intends to
deal in concrete statements and not in
vague generalities.
We would like to urge that some of
the more competent among the diners this
evening give Rabbi Wise a stiff quizzing
on the subject. To have gotten the hold
which it seems to have upon the German people Hitlerism must have something to recommend it—at least to
Germans. Whether it be an innate longing of a national culture which it satisfies,
or merely the devilish terrorism of an
individual in complete power is a matter
of some interest.

Active work on the 1934 Hullabaloo will begin with a meeting
of the members and candidates for
the business staff of the yearbook
at 12:20, in the publication's office,
Levering Hall. Candidates for the
editorial and photographic staffs, as
well as present members of these
staffs, will meet for assignments on
Friday, October 20, at 12:20.
According to Ted Stern, editorin-chief of the annual, the edition
will present a complete departure
from all previous standards. The
size of the book will be greatly increased. Individual photographs of
every undergraduate, classified according to year of residence in the
University, will be included in the
book.
Picture Calendar

Another feature is to be a ninepage picture calendar of the year
in retrospect. Instead of the usual
photographs of the campus buildings, the yearbook will contain
thirty-six original etchings of the
various parts of the University.
The plates for these etchings have
been, for the most part, presented
by the artists themselves.

The Dormitory is defined as the
home of either a fraternity man or
of a freshman. The president of the
Interfraternity Board has the authority to permit any special trips
to be made by freshmen and fraternity men. In the event that such
permission is granted, the president
is to be held personally liable to
the board to see that there are no
infractions of these rules by the
fraternity or fraternities receiving
such permission.
The rushing season for the year
1933-34 shall begin at 8:00 a. m. on
Wednesday, February 7, before
which time no engagement or date
for any time during the rushing season shall be made by fraternity men
with men in their first year of residence. Rushing shall be permitted
only on or after the said Wednesday
except as stated below.
On Friday, October 20, November 3 and 17, December 8 and 15,
and January 12, freshmen may visit
the various fraternity houses beginning at 8:00 a. m. until 1:00 a. m.
Lunch may be served to the freshmen but they must not stay to dinner. The freshmen may return later
in the evening to dance by the radio

as may be chosen. The fraternities
may not have an orchestra.
Invitations to these open houses
must be placed in the hands of an
officer of the board by the fraternities on Monday of the week of
their open house. The officer will
place the invitations in the University P. 0. boxes of the first year
men on that Monday. After Monday of each week of open houses invitations are unrestricted for that
week.
The fraternities should be divided
into three groups, each group having two open houses. The groups
shall have open houses alternately
on the dates given above.
Beginning on Thursday, February 8, 1934, a period of allotted
open houses shall exist, on which
days the designated fraternities shall
be permitted to entertain men in
their first year of residence, provided
that said entertainment shall be restricted to said fraternity house, the
Barn, or Levering Hall* On such
allotted days the designated fraternities shall enjoy priority over all
other fraternities, but in the event
that two fraternities shall share the
SANDWICHES

If parties are held on these days, the
freshmen must bear their share of
any expenses. There shall be a
silent period from midnight, Saturday, February 17, until 3:00 p. m.
Sunday, February 18, during which
time there shall be no communication of any sort between fraternity
men (including alumni) and men
in their first year of residence.
After presentation of bids at 3:00
p. m. Sunday, February 18, there
shall be open and unrestricted rushing. No fraternity man is to be at
the home of the freshman before
2:45 p. m. Sunday, February 18.
The constitution of the Interfraternity Board provides for a fine of
from $1.00 to $100.00 for any infringement of the above rules. Any
violations of the agreement shall be
tried by the Interfraternity Board.
It is the duty of each and every
member of the Board to report any
violation of the rules set down
above.
